comments:
I get the following error when trying to run my plugin(s) in a runtime workbench.  This worked just fine yesterday, but now I can't get anything (of mine) to run.  I'm sure there must be something I've done, but I can't figure out what.  None of my manifest.mf files have changed, none of my .classpath or .project files have changed.  I really need help because I can't work at all right not.  Your assistance is much appreciated.

Okay, I found the problem and it was my fault.  However, I intend to leave this bug open, because I think Eclipse could have handled the problem better.  It turns out that I was getting a NullPointerException in some of my <clinit> code (static variables) but Eclipse wouldn't tell me that.  I had to dig and dig and dig in despair.  It seemed like a classpath issue, because of all the other ClassNotFoundExceptions, when really it was just a NullPointerException.  The problem of reporting the error seems to be in AbstractBundle#loadBundleActivator() (line 151 in my version: 3.1) where it catches the throwable and then does the following:

throw new BundleException(NLS.bind(Msg.BUNDLE_INVALID_ACTIVATOR_EXCEPTION, activatorClassName, bundledata.getSymbolicName()), t);

The t (throwable) does not seem to be very well used in the message that is delivered to the user (me).  It would have been nice to see the original error with its stack trace.  With that information I would have been able to spare hours of my time and find (and fix) my bug sooner.  As it is, the error message is vague at best and misleading at worst.

Please find a way to address this issue.

Downgrading and moving to Equinox as the user has resolved the problem.

Updating the summary to reflect the work to do...  that is, improve the reporting of errros on classload failure during activation.

We'll see what we can do.

This is strange.  I can reproduce, but it only appears to cause problems when trying to load the invalid class for a second time.  The first time we try to load an activator with an error in <init> ExceptionInInitializerError is thrown and I see something like this in the log:

I admit this is a much more useful error.  But if I try to start the bundle a second time (which causes the activator to load again) then I get the NoClassDefFoundError thrown by the VM.  It appears the VM marks the class as bad and never really tries to run the <init> again.  There is nothing we can do in this case.  Keith, can you please attach the full log file when you get this error.  Thanks.
There is nothing we can do here.  The VM refuses to attempt to load a class a second time if it failed in <init> the first time.

(In reply to comment #4)
> There is nothing we can do here.  The VM refuses to attempt to load a class a
> second time if it failed in <init> the first time.
> 

The original reporter described an NPE in <clinit>, you tested an error in <init>. Perhaps you should also test <clinit> NPE?

I meant <clinit> see the following portion of the stacktrace from comment 3.  I did test <clinit>

Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
        at hello.world.rcp.Activator.<clinit>(Activator.java:13)

Errors in construction or <init> do not cause NoClassDefFoundError on subsequent class loads of the activator class.  This only occurs if <clinit> fails.
